title: Cutaneous Melanoma
diagnosis_topic: Pigmented lesion concerning for melanoma with staging considerations
setup_script: A 38-year-old man presents with a dark mole on his upper back that has recently changed in size and color. He reports occasional itching but no bleeding.

dynamic_flow.reply: Asymmetric pigmented plaque measuring 9 mm with irregular borders and color variegation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs excisional biopsy with narrow margin
dynamic_flow.reply: Entire lesion removed; pathology reports superficial spreading melanoma with Breslow depth 1.2 mm, no ulceration.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident determines need for sentinel lymph node biopsy
dynamic_flow.reply: Indicated for melanomas >1 mm thickness; schedule concurrently with wide excision.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident plans wide local excision
dynamic_flow.reply: 1-2 cm margin based on depth; closure to be performed primarily or with flap.
Not routinely indicated for stage IB melanoma without symptoms.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If sentinel node is positive on pathology
dynamic_flow.reply: Discuss completion lymphadenectomy vs. active surveillance and adjuvant immunotherapy (e.g., nivolumab).
Risk of local recurrence and metastasis increases.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates patient on skin self-exam and UV protection
dynamic_flow.reply: Emphasize avoidance of sunburns and tanning beds.
Consider if multiple primary melanomas or family history suggests CDKN2A mutations.
Dermatologic and surgical follow-up every 3-6 months for the first 2 years, then annually.
Immunotherapy or targeted therapy for stage III-IV disease.

critical_decision_points: Appropriate biopsy technique for suspicious pigmented lesions
Use of Breslow depth to guide excision margins and sentinel node biopsy
Decision-making for adjuvant therapy and nodal management
Patient education on self-examination and sun protection
